subject: dbusconfiguration: Init margin similar to temp

Patch Set 1:

Same strange Jenkins internal error as 36625. Code builds and runs fine on my machine.

Intentionally setting timeout to 0 if it is a D-Bus passive sensor,
because most sensor services do not update their values if unchanged,
so a sensor that remains stable for a long period of time
might be falsely considered timed out.

It would be nice if D-Bus sensors also had a "last good" timestamp,
that would always be updated, even if the value is unchanged,
so that other services like this could confirm they are still alive.

Patch Set 6:

OK, figured it out the hard way, why "ignoreDbusMinMax" is forced to true if it's a "temp" PID loop. There's another bug somewhere, causing the input to be normalized, but the setpoint is not normalized, causing bad PID loop math.

Setting "ignoreDbusMinMax" to true, suppresses this bug. So, I'm also doing this for "margin" PID loop type, to treat similarly to "temp", matching the existing behavior that people will expect (ironically, fixing this bug would break existing behavior, so I'm hesitant to actually fix this bug).

Tested: if I don't do this, I reproduce this bug. If I add this workaround, the bug goes away, and my margin loops look and perform much better.
Set Ready For Review

Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

I think timestamp is nice concept to have, so the sensor consumer can decide whether to wait or not across sensors with different polling rates.

Patch Set 6:

(3 comments)

> Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1
> 
> I think timestamp is nice concept to have, so the sensor consumer can decide whether to wait or not across sensors with different polling rates.

See comment on the line.  That effectively doubles the dbus traffic, and would likely halve our performance.

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1
> 
> I think timestamp is nice concept to have, so the sensor consumer can decide whether to wait or not across sensors with different polling rates.

Unfortunately, timestamp doesn't work with D-Bus "passive" sensors. That's the key, passive. Nothing happens until the sensor gets updated, as they work on a push model: there is no regularly scheduled poll for updates. Instead, the dbus-sensors drivers push new values whenever they feel like it: could be fast, could be slow, it's totally up to the driver when it wants to push. There's no timeout enforcement possible, under this model, hence me wanting to make sure the timeout feature is disabled.

We had a lively discussion earlier about adding a last-known-good-reading timestamp, and a redundant keepalive write of the same sensor value, to the dbus-sensors model. (It might have been on another patch, but I searched and couldn't find it.) This would nicely solve the problem of being unable to distinguish a stuck/broken sensor from a good steady sensor that simply hasn't changed its reading in a long time. The consensus is that D-Bus has performance issues already, and these features would slow down the system too much, for relatively little gain.

Patch Set 18:

(1 comment)
Won't this affect the configuration of temp sensors?

Good point. I'm not sure why the original code wanted to force "ignoreDbusMinMax" to true, for temp sensors, but not for margin sensors, interestingly enough. Most of the math in the inner PID loop routine already takes in scaled values, between 0.0 (min) and 1.0 (max), so if temperature were not also scaled, it would make the math really weird. It seems to me that it works better when all values are scaled.
I'm still up in the air about this. If "ignoreDbusMinMax" is true, it defeats scaling.
Found why it's here, it works around a bug. See latest patchset.
Tested statement?
Good catch. Added it, in next patchset.

This would increase dbus-traffic, by doubling the number of PropertiesChanged messages on dbus which would defeat the whole purpose of only sending sensor value changes;  We'd need to find a different solution.
Yep, this comment was optimistic. Will change the comment.

This is a bigger question around what "alive" means.  Dbus/systemd has a definition: "is responding to pings and message inquiries"  If a sensor daemon is misbehaved, the system will restart it, which phosphor-pid-control can see.
Same.
Commit message line-wrapping seems a bit oddly narrow, fwiw...
I was wrapping the text earlier based on the sentence structure, instead of just at a hardcoded right margin. Will revise it.
I have rewritten this comment.
I rewrote the commit message, to reflect modern reality.
Rebased to latest master. No other changes made.

I tested this with the a config including the following fragment:

```
{
        "name": "TSI0_TEMP",
        "type": "temp",
        "readPath": "/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/TSI0_TEMP",
        "timeout": 5.0,
        "ignoreDbusMinMax": true
}
```

The timeout setting is bogus and based on a misunderstanding, but by my understanding this patch should correct it and set the timeout to zero anyway, matching the behavior I get if I edit the config to do that explicitly.  However, in practice that doesn't seem to happen -- with the config edit it works as desired, but with the above config and this patch I'm still getting the failsafe oscillation I'd been getting previously due to the timeout expiring between the arrivals of value-changed signals.
Thanks for testing

Bizarre. What happens if you remove the "timeout" parameter configured here in the JSON? I think that what's going on is the JSON value is overriding the default of zero that's trying to be established by this patch. Ideally, the "timeout" parameter should not appear at all, in any sensor that's a D-Bus passive (pushed in whenever a change happens) sensor.

Aside from a slight difference in how quickly the failsafe kicks in due to the default being 2 seconds instead of 5 seconds, I get the same behavior with the timeout parameter removed entirely as I do with it set to 5.0 as above.

Oh, now I see why it's not taking effect -- this is only in the path for dbus-based configurations, whereas I'm using a standalone json config file.  Can we just augment the patch with analogous code to handle that path as well?
That's a good idea. It's unfortunate that the code has two parallel code paths like this. I haven't yet used the combination of D-Bus passive sensors with the standalone hardcoded JSON configuration.

> It's unfortunate that the code has two parallel code paths like this.

Agreed -- it'd be nice of course to find a single spot to put this logic that would apply to both without just duplicating it, but I haven't looked through the code enough to know if such a spot exists.
I might get some time again to work on this. However, I don't use the standalone JSON configuration, so wouldn't be able to test it. Any thoughts?

I do not use the standalone JSON configuration, so have been unable to test it. Does anybody use this, and if so, would you be willing to test it? The standalone uses a different code path. Some things might need to be synchronized between these code paths, as they have drifted over time.
Is this part of the comment stale at this point?  From the discussion on discord it sounds like we can achieve proper failsafe behavior by having dbus-sensors daemons report NaNs to signal failures.
Yes, that's correct. Will revise the text.
I have removed this misleading and obsolete comment.

Happily, this patch is much less invasive than it was before. It turns out the "timeout = 0" and "ignoreDbusMinMax = true" settings were already made by other patches since this was originally written, as the same bugs they fix were noticed by others. All that remained to be done was having it apply to all non-fan PID classes, not just "temp".
This PR is prepare for issue #23?

I actually hadn't thought of that. Issue #23 is for a new feature, but this is an old patch that fixes an old bug, in which "margin" class was not being initialized similarly to "temp" class, as it should have been.
Oh, I see. I agree to add margin type. Only static json support "margin" seems a little weird.
seems doesn't need this include?
Good catch. I'm not sure how that got in there. I will try removing it and recompiling.
I have removed that header line.
seems include again
Wow, good catch! It must have crept in when rebasing. Removed it again.
Could we add unit test coverage here?

Hmm. That might be tricky. There's no good test cases now for D-Bus passive (aka entity-manager) configuration of PID loops. There's a test for an individual passive sensor, and there's a test for configuration direct from a JSON file (not the modern code path which uses passive sensors and configuration from EntityManager). Adding a test case that covers this would be a new feature that would be best in a separate patch.

Giving +2 to myself, after multiple +1 from others.

After a little over two years, it feels good to finally get this in!
